column3: United States;Bock- Heller Bock / Maibock;Sprague Farm & Brew Works;On tap at the Bocktown. Cloudy dark brown with a big foamy head. This almost looks like a weizen bock. Not too sure if it is truly opaque but it is getting there. Slightly roasty aroma but the smell is barely detectable. Initially the taste comes on like a stout
column4: almost impy stoutish. Then the flavors meld into that typical bock characteristic. Interesting evolution of flavors. The bock flavors then proceed to overwhelm the palate. Roasty
column5: then alky malty bitterness. However
column6: the bitterness is not excessive like many bocks. This stuff is more like a mild impy stout or baltic porter than a bock. Mild carbonation. Quite surprising. If you like baltic or impy stout
column7: give this a try just for the fun of it. Medicinal bitter lasting finish.

column3: United States;Bock- Heller Bock / Maibock;Rock Bottom Pittsburgh;Did you ever check out how messed up the listings are for the Rock Bottom brews? Terribly confusing! On tap at the Pittsburgh Rock Bottom. Sweetish plastic aroma. Ubiquitous pale yellow american lager color. Laid back flavor at first but then the alky impact develops and gives you a slight alky wallop. It fools you into thinking it is mild then the impact occurs
column4: quite interesting. Alky impact slowly builds with each sip. This light colored bock is OK but you certainly can tell the alky content is higher than most of the brews at Rock Bottom. Leaves a medium alky bitterness as a finish that hangs for a while after the last sip.

column3: United States;Pale Ale - American / APA;J.T. Whitneys Pub & Brewery;On tap at brewpub Once they gave me a pour that was worth drinking this did not turn out so badly. The first pint was a horror story though. It arrived just as the tap line was being replaced (but not cleaned). As a result I got 12 ounces of sediment. You’d think the bartender would have noticed. At least they were prompt in bringing a new one. Aroma / Appearance - A one finger white head balanced on the top of an orange colored body. Grapefruit
column4: pine
column5: lemons and orange rinds highlight the nose which also is supported by a basic maltiness blended in caramel. It’s not exceptionally complex but it is good enough. Flavor / Palate - Pine and grapefruit reveal the hoppy nature of this beer. Caramel unfolds as the chewy mouthfeel fills every crevice of the palate. I am reminded most of orange liquer but with a yeasty aftertaste. It tastes pretty good especially when you get a pour that is not 95% chud.

column1: Big Bear Mountain Orange Blossom Amber Ale;Big Bear Lake
column3: United States;Flavored - Fruit;Big Bear Mountain Brewery;Served on tap at Big Bear Mountain Brewery. The appearance is a slightly hazy golden orange hue. The aromas are strong with a McDonald’s Orange Drink aroma that takes me back to me T-ball days. I dig it. The flavors have a powdery orange taste that runs through the beer. Light hop additions. If you like fake orange drinks you’ll love this brew. The mouth is nicely carbonated (unlike most of their beers this evening). I enjoyed this one.

column5: orange rinds
column6: and Vick’s Vapor Rub work well to clear a sinus problem but aren’t really what I look for in a beer. T: This is what a mixture of orange peel infused cologne and Vick’s Vapor Rub would taste like. Simply dreadful and it burns a little bit. M: The body is thin with almost no carbonation and an intense heat as though taking a drink of liquor. D: Truly dreadful. This might be good for a head cold
column7: but it’s nothing I would ever wish to drink again.

column10: (Two Rivers Beverage Co. in Two Rivers

column12: kudos to Rail House for reviving this historical brand of the very distant past.

column4: the bulk of which came from the side of the brewery walls. I can remember the grassy resins that stuck to my hands and the pleasant feeling of falling sleep six times as I sifted out hops that were too green. The scent of lupulin on my hands is just the same as the aroma that came from a freshly poured pint. It was a grassy punch in the face on a lovely light amber beer. One sided toward the use of hops
column5: but something well remembered.

column5: crisp caramel malts with some sweet apples and toasted bread. But the most interesting aspect is the lightly sour
column6: vinous aroma with hints of sour cherries and oak. Interesting. The taste is even more sour with the initial taste being the tart cherries and acidic barrel character. The caramel malts and bread are present in the background but it’s less prevalent than the dry wine-like presence. The finish is dry and oaky with a red wine presence. The mouthfeel is lightly carbonated with a dry tannic presence and a bit of funk. This is a different take on a doppelbock with the uniqueness of the wine barrel really taking things in a different direction. Another interesting from The Livery.

column3: Canada;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Columbia Brewery (Labatt - AB InBev);"Yowch! What weight has my review after Josh’s Opus on corporate brewing boardroom banality....the market hype for this beer may be the product of insulated executive trend mongering
column4: but the brewer took the right direction at least in a small way...it is at least
column5: a light/pale all-malt lager. ...decent heading
column6: fair aroma of sweet malts ( unlike it’s sibling Kokanee which has a 25% dextrin bite and body). Problem with this beer is although it has a light malt character it is very thin in the body and watery in the mouth...of course I served it at a proper serving temp for a all malt beer about 48-50 deg. F....I suppose they(Inbev marketers) have designs of serving it as half frozen slush like Coors. So from the brewery;s accountant and brew master’s perspective you don’t want to waste a lot of good malt on a drink who’s main sales pitch is selling the taste of ice when it is served far too cold to taste...besides good malt protein just clouds up the drink at those temperatures....they want ice ya give em ice...not rich malting."

Good tingly mild carbonation. Has some roasty hints in there and perhaps I do detect a little chocolate during the session. Cannot taste any bananas due to the overwelming coriander and clove spices. I’m a wheat beer lover but this JH wheat has a bit too much spice for my girlie taste buds. Finish has a lasting medium low alky industrial bitterness on the back of the throat.

United States;IPA;John Harvards Brewhouse Monroeville;"On tap at Kelly’s Bar
column4: Pittsburgh. This beer is a part of the supposed ""Wet Hop Festival."" Dubbed Fresh Hop IPA for this version with ""wet hops."" From Steve Sloan
column5: head brewer at John Harvards: ""The fresh hop IPA was basically our Old Willy IPA that was ""wet-hopped"" with 22 lbs of freshly picked cascade hops from Pedersen Farms in Upstate NY. This gives the nice floral character to the beer. We normally ""dry hop"" the IPA with 6 lbs of previously kilned hops which gives the beer a more citrusy quality. A good amount of caramel malt is added to the IPA to balance the high bitterness (80 bitterness units) from the use of 5 different varieties of hops during the brewing process
column6: thus resulting in a sweeter version of IPA. Alcohol by volume is approx. 6.5%"" Dark caramel ruby
column7: off white head. Aroma is tangerine
column10: vanilla (quite smooth and sweet). Flavor is hoppy with walnuts
column11: maple syrup ice cream and some lingering bitterness. Quite an unusual flavor."

column3: Canada;IIPA - Imperial / Double IPA;Half Pints Brewing Co.;Appearance: A deep-orange brown body with a healthy 2-3 finger head. Body is quite hazy with a dark brown cloud right in the middle of it that slowly goes upward. Lots of lacing left on the side of the glass. Digging the look of this brew. Smell: Not as strong as i would have liked but a good resinous hoppy aroma with a dose of malt. A bit of orange & pine thrown into the mix. Taste: Malt hits me first mixed in with a nice edge to it. Slowly leaves the place to a surprisingly sweet taste. Good dollop of hops but not overdone. Has a sugary aspect to it. Finishes with a spice-like bite and a good piney aftertaste. Mouthfeel: Very smooth with an medium body. Good balance but i found it ended just a little bit thin for my taste. Bitterness isn’t quite up there for a 100 IBU beer. It’s still quite good in the palate though.

column1: Hylands Sturbridge Industrial Pale Ale;East Haven
column3: United States;IPA;Pioneer Beer Company (Connecticut Valley Brewing);In short: A typical caramelized
column4: fruity and resinous IPA. Above average How: Tap at Vermont Brewer’s Festival 2010. Simply called Pioneer Brewing IPA
column5: I’m assuming this is the beer The look: Clear golden body topped by a small off-white head In long: The typical but always pleasant hoppy nose has citrus fruits upfront backed-up by grass. The nourishing body is well malted with plenty of cookies and luscious fruity caramel. Finish brings a round fruity and resinous bitterness that is never aggressive. Light citric notes. Nothing original. I’ve had IPAs just like this one many many times before and I hope to have many other similar examples. This is the best beer I’ve ever had from this brewery. I’m looking to trying a second one.

Australia;Tripel;Dark Isle Brewery;This was the hardest craft brewer to find while I was in Tasmania. I’d ask about it everywhere I went
column3: but more then half of people hadn’t even heard of it! Finally a helpful publican pointed me in the right direction
column4: and I was able to purchase the second-last mixed sixpack of Dark Isle brews from a 9-11 bottleshop on Davey Street in Hobart. This one poured a hazy chestnut colour with a modest eggshell head. Right from the start this seems a little overcarbonated. Aroma is sweet and fruity
column5: berries come to mind. This beer feels thin and fizzy in the mouth
column6: and this really seems to steal away any structure the dark malts may provide
column7: and this beer ends up being a mouthful of fruity caramel blandness. When I came to rate it I was surprised at its designation as a belgian strong ale (there is no mention or hint of what style this is on the bottle
column8: other than the claim of using five different malts). It is worth stating that I have no idea how fresh this sample is as there was no best-before date on the bottle or the carton.

column3: United States;Berliner Weisse;Herkimer Pub & Brewery;Very clear blonde colour with a fairly small head that was really just a coating on top. The aroma was kind of wheat with some lactic funk. It is very clean if that makes sense. Light on the palate and carbonation. The flavor is faint but it is there. There isn’t a whole lot in the begining but the tart flavors quickly come out. There is a sour candy like sweetness to this with a dry sour finish. It isn’t the best example of the style but I sure do applaud them dfor doing it.

United States;Berliner Weisse;Herkimer Pub & Brewery;Draft at the brewpub. Poured into a chalice that must have weighed at least a pound. Hazy light gold with almost no head. Rich and creamy body with nice acidity and a decent amount of carbonation. Flavor was creamy
column4: citrusy and acidic. Quite dry. Hints of granny smith apples with a bit of sweet malt. Very refreshing and thirst quenching. Sour

column1: 5 Seasons North Whisky Barrel Aged Quinte55ence;Alpharetta
column3: United States;Quadrupel / Abt;5 Seasons North;750ml bottle. Pours extremely dark murky mahogany
column4: almost black actually
column5: with almost no carbonation visible at all. A few stray bubbles that recede immediately to nothing. The aroma is big and complex with whiskey and vanilla up front but then comes raisins
column8: leather and caramel. Little bit of wood coming through. The taste is even better and one of the better Belgians I’ve tasted. Initial wave is vanilla
column9: oak and leather. But immediately following that is a much sweeter chocolate and dark fruit character. The sweetness then subsides to a dry
column10: warming finish with whiskey and oak. Sublime taste. The mouthfeel
column12: keeps this from being a world class brew. It’s just under carbonated
column13: pure and simple. It’s not completely flat
column14: but close and is enough to knock this down a notch. This beer has the potential to bee of the best beers I’ve ever had. The aroma and flavor are sublime but the carbonation detracts from the beer. I’m looking forward to trying this with proper carbonation and we’d be talking about an unbelievable beer.

M - Medium body with moderate to high carbonation. Sweet

column3: United States;Tripel;Tröegs Brewing Company;"A solid pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces a two finger thick
column4: pale tan tinged

column11: but quite light bodied for a beer of this strength. It does have some viscous heft to it as it clings just a bit to the palate. The beer finishes with spicy clove and a hint of woody pepper notes. Up front fruit flavors of pear and floral apple are more noticeable than the melon from the aroma
column12: but there are some honeydew melon flavors here as well. The malt has notes of freshly crushed pale malt
column14: as well as some sweet grain character. A touch of oxidation seems to add a hint of almost caramelized character to the malt towards the finish; it boosts the complexity more than anything. A touch of higher alcohols accentuate some warmth towards the finish
column15: but much of this is due to the 10.1% abv alone and this is actually fairly muted given this beer’s strength. This one is barely showing its age yet. There is a hint of oxidation around the edges
column16: but it is so light still that it is only accentuating other components of this beer. This is still quite a nice Tripel and even tastes in better shape than many a “fresh” overseas example that sometimes shows up in stores here in the states. I can’t see this aging a whole lot better here on out and would recommend drinking these now; any more oxidation will likely start to hurt the flavor of this beer."

United States;IPA;FireHouse Grill & Brewery;Tasted on tap at the 2nd Annual Drakes IPA Festival. This IPA pours a light yellow gold color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is fleetingly floral and earthy. A medium bodied IPA. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are earthy and floral. A medium bitter IPA. A touch drier than the others here today. Good balance. Nice carbonation. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

United States;IPA;FireHouse Grill & Brewery;Sampled this brew alongside their ’regular IPA.’ According to the waitress this beer is brewed with one single hop variety. My guess is it’s the new hop called BRAVO (just a hunch). This another nice hoppy brew from the Firehouse Brewery. This time it has less of that classic citrus aroma/flavor and more of the pine. Still has a good amount of malt to balance out the brew. Just enough bitterness rounds out the medium body.Pretty decent beer here.

column4: bright golden yellow colored body with some visible streams of carbonation and a creamy white head. The head is average in size and has good retention. It has nice citrusy hops with mild bitterness and light spice that mix with sweet lightly toasted gain and wheat flavors. A sweet grainy and very mellow alcohol gives some warmth and sophistication. It finishes clean with a slight hop presence. The palate has a very smooth texture with soft yet active carbonation with in a medium to full body.

column5: sustained white head. The aroma is a balance between sweet caramel with a touch of toffee and a hoppy bitterness - grapefruit

Very fruity in the aroma with overipe rasberry and bramble notes. Very refreshing mouthfeel. Initial sweet and soft summer fruit flavours in the mouth with little pale malt presence. Delicate floral hop resins slowly appear in the not too drying aftertaste
column5: giving a very refreshing finish which would be ideal for a summer session. Never seen this ale on draught in my part of the world but I think it would be a very popular choice and we need more this type rather than the current plethora of golden ales being touted last summer. Highly recommended.

column3: United States;Belgian Ale - Pale / Golden;Portsmouth Brewery;"Draught snifter at the brewery on 7/6/07 Definitely an interesting take on a ""Grand Cru"" though there certainly are other examples of mid-gravity Belgian grand crus out there. column4: fully dissipating beige head. Light carbonation in the liquid. Rather sweet

column7: something like allspice or heavily candied ginger. Moderate esterization is evident on the finish
column9: though the nose certainly dosent display any vast complexity. The yeast didnt seem like it did a whole lot of work here

column11: with lots of focus on the caramel
column12: toffee and spicing. No flaws. Sweet again in flavor
column14: raisins and hints of chocolate on the finish. Toffee throughout most of it
column15: with vanilla and clove/allspice spicing adding some intrigue. Very low
column16: exceedingly loose carbonation is its greatest fault
column17: giving the beer too little apparent body and showing some thinning/wateriness on the end. Alcohol warmth is sligthly apparent
column18: though certainly not problematic or fuselic."

column1: North Country Breakfast Blend Mild;Slippery Rock
column3: United States;Mild Ale;North Country Brewing Company;Pours brown with a thin khaki head. column1: North Country Breakfast Blend Mild;Slippery Rock
column3: United States;Mild Ale;North Country Brewing Company;Sampled at Penn Brewery. This beer started with so much in the aroma. The aroma was HUGE! Very strong creamy caramel with a hint of toastiness. The pour was a dark brown with a one finger off white head. Taste was where the let down came. There wasn’t any. It seemed to just turn to water in the mouth. I know mild ales are very weak ABV-wise
column4: but it’s possible to give them flavor while maintaining the weakness. Decent carbonation for the style
column5: however. If this had a little more flavor it could be great.

column1: North Country Breakfast Blend Mild;Slippery Rock
column3: United States;Mild Ale;North Country Brewing Company;A- Dark translucent red/brown body with 1/2 finger creamy off-white head. Good head retention and leaves behind a good amount of lacing at first-but the head eventually fades along with its ability to leave behind lacing. S- Big smell for such a little beer. Rich toasty chocolate malt up front with hints of caramel malt behind it. T- Rich toasted chocolate malt upfront with solid caramel malt backbone-reminiscent of a unsweetened caramel coffee. This flavor last the whole way through with a mild bitter coffee flavor remaining. Taste is very similar to this brewery’s feedbag stout-big taste for such a little beer. P- Low carbonation and rather thin body. O- This is a good drinkable brew. The flavor is too big for a long session ale (for me at least)-but the low ABV makes it great for any time of the day and the flavor you get is well worth it. A great low ABV beer to have when you don’t want an alcohol kick. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 08-25-2007 22:17:20

United States;Pilsener - Imperial;Carolina Brewing Company;The aroma was fruity and malty with a sweetness and a lightly spicy hop presence. The aroma was citrusy with a candy characteristic. The beer arrived crystal clear pale golden with a low persistent white head. The flavor was malty and fruity with a moderate level of bittering and a citrusy character. The hops also presented as spicy and sweet malt with candy was also present. The body was medium-full with a moderate level of carbonation. The beer was a bit thick on the palate but the finish was dry with substantial bittering lasting into the aftertaste. A very tasty brew with some warming notable post consumption. Pint(s) at the release party at 42nd Street Oyster Bar (July 3

column3: United States;Saison / Farmhouse / Grisette;Green Flash Brewing Company;2012 22 oz Bomber I expected to throw away this bottle
column4: seeing that saisons are very delicate and that this is a session level abv (4.5%) beer. NOT Appearance: deep golden with a lovely thick
column5: frothy off white head about an inch in height. this head has excellent retention (even after minutes there’s still a quarter inch there) and nice lacing rings are observed. Aroma: slight funk
column6: bretty aroma is prevalent. phenolics and spices are present (something I couldn’t figure out turns out to be ginger
column7: its subtle). no trans 2 nonenal oxidation is detected. just a light solventy thing going on in the background... Palate: body is medium and texture very creamy which follows the look of the foam. carbonation is lively and astringency very soft. The finish is short and very dry. A good trait in a saison. Taste: just slightly sour (not even quite tart). light wheat cereal malt flavors combine with orange and spices and mild hop bitterness. the ginger has almost disappeared. very mellow. Overall: wow. a 4.5% almost 5 year old beer has almost no aging elements (off flavors and/or aromas)??? it’s maybe mellowed to a point where some might find it uninteresting. but its subtle funkyness and soft spices make it a very enjoyable session beer.

column4: well that explains why it’s really inviting then. There’s a slight musky mead-like character too. Yup I’m liking this so far. Crikey. That’s a real smack in the chops. Amazing tart pear flavour. Really good wood and lemony acidity with some intense but never overpowering sweet notes. This is full on stuff. Amazingly juicy. It storms around the palate bagging a wooden spoon on a saucepan and demanding to be attended to. The finish is truly epic. Amazing length. Christ on a bike. This is a big one. I don’t want it to finish. Luckily it seems like it’s not going to. Each sip just adds to the intensity of what is already in the mouth. Bloody brilliant perry.

Hope to one day find a fresher more hoppy bottle.

column4: July 2007 This beer is a full amber color and is topped by a wispy
column5: tan
column6: ring of a head. The aroma is quite fruity with solid notes of berries (definitely leans quite strongly towards blackberries)

column9: despite not being overly sour. There is some sort of chewy fruit-skin like flavor; something like cherry skins
column10: blackberry skins; it definitely gives this an austere
column11: slightly tannic finish that is almost wood like in its concentrated fruit skin character (my guess is that the oak has something to do with this as well). This beer is nicely tart; it leans towards a lactic & fruity acidity. This beer is quite fruity
column12: without being sweet & somehow this accents the tartness. It is surprising how much the pinot grapes have added to the overall fruit notes found in this beer. This beer actually almost has more fruit character than sour funk
column13: but that may be my sour craving preferences talking. The body has a surprising fullness to it that
column15: must have been influenced by the barrel aging. This is quite nice
column16: and I was not expecting anything nearly this good."

column3: United States;Sour / Wild Beer;Craftsman Brewing Company;Hard to do but this is a combo of both 2010 and 2011 versions sampled at Stone Sour Fest 2011. Two totally different beers but both excellent for different reasons. I’ll try to merge these and still tell the difference based on notes. A: on both this is outstanding with neither jumping ahead of one another. The lavender comes out a great deal as does some of the sour elements. Slightly more citrus and acidity in the ’11. T: Totally different beers. The ’10 is a mild
column4: slightly sour beer with flavors more muted and easy to drink. I love lavender and find this very much associated with summer. If they sold this in bottles I would buy cases. The ’11 is overly sour with mouth puckering qualities. Over the top and a beer I had been looking for that really gives your stomach that nice sour feel. You can’t drink a lot of this yet the sweetness and lavender still come through. Overall
column5: ’10 is a session sour
column6: ’11 is a sour you can have 4oz of.

column4: July 2007 This has only a dusting of a head
column5: appears to have a very low carbonation. The beer is a chocolate to black color. This definitely smells like a stout
column8: concentrated malty character. Underneath the dominant roast driven aromatics is a solid fruitiness of blackened plums & raisins moving towards an almost brandy or rum like note that seems to accent some oak barrel character. Dusty cocoa aromatics are noticeable in the nose as well
column9: but this is really fruity smelling at times. In fact I get a pronounced blackberry note that is so distinct it almost seems like some of them have been added. The taste is quite fruity up front
column10: yet it still maintains quite a dry character overall. The fruitiness is defined by a distinct blackberry flavor that becomes tart and roasted in the middle through to the finish. The pronounced blackberry note comes through in the finish again and lingers long after the beer has left my mouth. The beer is fairly light feeling in the mouth
column11: but it is still rich and almost chewy
column12: which is quite good for a soured beer (or is that the color that makes me think it is rich; I don’t think that is the entire story though). The blackberry note is so pronounced
column13: I almost wonder are these actually somehow involved (what was in the barrel
column14: hell what type of barrel was it). Oaky barrel notes are also noticeable (mostly in the finish); spicy wood notes
column16: an austere tannic palate coating character. The stout flavors here are definitely noticeable
column17: but not dominantly so; a roast acidity and a character of a smooth
column18: first pull espresso are definitely noticed
column19: but the Stout character is more apparent in the aroma than in the flavor. The barrel for this beer mush have had something in it prior to this beer (Brandy
column20: or more likely some berry like red wine). The blackberry note I have been talking about is not the dominant character here
column21: but it adds such an intriguing accent that is just so apparent. This is very good
column22: much better than I was expecting. I really like how rich this beer is
column23: yet it is still quite quaffable & I really like how this beer melds all of the interesting flavor components."

column8: ring-like and a few sparse islands of amber froth of a head. Underneath the tartness & fruit aromatics is a real

This really might just be the raspberry seed / skin notes (assuming whole fruit was used). The beer also has a lightly sweet aromatic bent to it. The taste is somewhat sweet
column12: but is still amazingly drinkable (once again thank the tartness for making this beer quaffable). This is fairly malty

column4: July 2007 This beer has quite a funky nose to it; it is so funky it seems almost unintentional. The aroma is lightly tart
column5: yet has caramel and toasted malt notes to it. It has a funky mustiness to it and almost a leather-like quality to it as well. The head has some good staying power and is light brown colored. The body of the beer is a hazy brown color. The taste is dry
column6: yet it still has quite the brown ale profile; notes of toasted malt
column9: biscuit like grain and a light burnt soda cracker flavor. This beer in some way is clean compared to other sour beers here today
column10: yet it still has a light tartness and even an underlying funkiness that some of the other sour beers have not had. This has a phenolic note that is almost plastic like and is a bit hot. This is actually a bit unbalanced as the phenolics seem to dominate the flavor profile after a bit. The brown grain character seems to accentuate the phenolics at times too. This definitely seems unintentionally funky to me; it doesn’t quite work
column11: but was still worth a try. The flavors are interesting (especially the combination of dark malts and funk)

column5: with a nitro cream head in oatmeal. Flavor begins with a distinct note of pan seared natural casing beef frank skin. This marries with an Indonesian raspberry candy and the loveliest mild stout background. The palate for this beer need not be covered over with raspberries and wieners. There’s a psychotically drinkable stout in the background. More perfectly quaffable than any dry stout I’ve experienced and right on par with many dark milds. Fortunately the fruit character fade and the hot dogs go to the back of the room with some chalk and I’m left practically guzzling this most refreshing of beers. Clear the way berries

column3: Australia;Blonde Ale / Golden Ale;Happy Goblin Brewery;650ml bottle (bottled on 18/4/13) at Yulli’s restaurant
column4: Sydney which has a fine beer list to go with the vegetarian food. The ABV is now 4.8% for this batch release. Appears clear amber-brown with a decent off white head. Nose has flowery perfumy hops (English-style) on top of a caramel malt bill. Palate is deliciously smooth and silky with lovely balanced flavours and a firm floral hop bitterness. It is medium bodied with perfect carbonation for the style which is really an English-style pale ale rather than a golden/blond ale as per description above. Excellent stuff - I was reminded of Seven Sheds’ Kentish Ale which is another fine Aussie version of this style. The larger bottle size is appropriate for this very sessionable ale.

column6: copper highlighted color when held up to the light. The aroma has a sweet fruitiness to it that reminds me of a combination of pear

column9: earthy note plays a secondary role here. Coming back to the nose after a bit has me noticeing an interesting kiwi note as well as other tart fruit aromas. The taste is fruity up front
column10: but quickly picks up a nice lactic tartness through the finish. A fizzy carbonation provides an effervescent prickle as it roles across the tongue
column11: which helps to lighten the body up. This beer is pretty dry
column12: but has more body to it than the dryness will suggest. The beer has a tannic
column13: spicy oak like character to it in the finish (though I wouldn’t necessarily say this was actually aged with oak). The fruitiness and tartness combines to suggest flavors of sour plums
column14: berries and lots of tamarind like flavors. The finish has a touch of acetic character to it that helps to spice things up a bit. This is quite nice
column15: I forgot that this was a sour beer; so I was expecting a Saison’ish thing; and am pleasantly surprised by the Flemish Sour like beer that ended up in my glass. The beer is perhaps a touch too fizzy from the ample carbonation
column16: but this is easily remedied by some aggressive swirling. This is a very nice beer that I am quite happy to be drinking."

column3: United States;Stout - Dry;Mountaineer Brewing Co.;A big thanks to Santa Adam for sending this my way. The bottle poured into a pint glass produced a finger worth of tan head that sat on top of a black bodied brew. I got a lot of roasted goodness coming from the nose typical chocolate and coffee notes filled my head. Flavor wise it mimics the nose but with a good balance of sweetness and roasted bitter making it rather drinkable. The mouthfeel was medium with good carbonation. I easily drank the bottle I had and could have had a few more. I was pleasantly surprised with this brewery and would be proud to call it my local brewer. Serving type: bottle

column4: soda-like receding head. Fruity pineapple like aroma. A bit of alcohol seems to be coming off as well. Strange sensation. Really tastes like a fruit soda with a thicker texture and a starchy finish. That pineapple fruit flavor is all over the place. Light apple cider up front
column5: and then becomes this thick and almost chalky. Has that weird finish that I don’t like so much that I might have a name for if I were a little more versed on sake. I like it

column1: Ume No Yado Tsukiusagi (Moon Rabbit) Sparkling Saké;Katsuragi-City Nara
column2: Japan;Saké - Infused;Ume No Yado Brewery;Trader Joe-San’s bottle. Pours looking like a sparkling lemonade
column3: the sake has a little bit of a head at first which is interesting and nothing I’ve ever seen before. The aroma is sweet and very floral
column4: light hints of alcohol & mild fruitiness. The taste is fairly sweet and loaded with nice pear notes. There is a light tartness here and some light alcohol. All together it’s pretty sweet
column5: but it’s very nice tasting... a tad drier and I’d love it.

column1: Ume No Yado Tsukiusagi (Moon Rabbit) Sparkling Saké;Katsuragi-City Nara
column2: Japan;Saké - Infused;Ume No Yado Brewery;Trader Joe’s label on this one. Pours a fizzy clear white. Aroma is weak... some faint booziness is about it. Flavor is very sweet up front... a nice blast of pear and table sugar. Alcohol and fizz take over down the home stretch. Interesting
column3: but not my thing.

column1: Ume No Yado Tsukiusagi (Moon Rabbit) Sparkling Saké;Katsuragi-City Nara
column2: Japan;Saké - Infused;Ume No Yado Brewery;Bottle as Trader Joe-San’s Sparkling Sake. This was unbearable. Aroma is a tape-like
column3: ethyl acetate and wet cardboard aroma. Pours a murky
column4: clouded rice water. Flavors are unbearably sweet
column5: tainted with some ridiculous pale fruit flavoring
column6: and the meager carbonation just makes this feel uneven and sickly. Would never buy again.

column1: Ume No Yado Tsukiusagi (Moon Rabbit) Sparkling Saké;Katsuragi-City Nara
column2: Japan;Saké - Infused;Ume No Yado Brewery;I had both the Ume No Yado and the Trader Joe’s Sparkling Sake side by side when tasting. Both poured a faint yellow with a small bubble white head that faded down pretty quickly. The TJ’s version was a tad bit darker yellow than what poured out of the Ume No Yado bottle. The UNY nose had a pretty sweet nose with notes of peach and pineapple. The TJs had a stronger peach presence than the UNY nose had. Flavor of the UMY was fairly sweet with a light note of peach and tropical fruity flavors but mostly was composed of flavors from the rice. TJs had a bit more tropical fruity sweetness with the rice flavors a bit more subdued. Body was light with lots of carbonation. I really did enjoy the sake’s. The nose was much strong in both than the flavors but it was very well balanced in the sake. Trader Joe’s is supposed to be the same thing but there are subtle differences in the flavors
column3: none of which would necessitate paying $3-5 more for the UNY.

column1: Ume No Yado Tsukiusagi (Moon Rabbit) Sparkling Saké;Katsuragi-City Nara
column2: Japan;Saké - Infused;Ume No Yado Brewery;Bottle 330ml. blue bottle @ post De Molen we want to goto bed Sake Tasting. Unclear light to medium grey yellow color with virtually none head. Aroma is moderate to heavy rice water
column3: rice wine
column4: blue berries. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a average to long duration
column5: blue berries. Body is medium

column1: Ume No Yado Tsukiusagi (Moon Rabbit) Sparkling Saké;Katsuragi-City Nara
column2: Japan;Saké - Infused;Ume No Yado Brewery;bottle at post De Molen we want to goto bed Sake tasting ... now i dont know how many sakes some of the other raters of this have had ... or if we just had a bad bottle but YEUCH... hazy yellow (like robinsons barley water juice) ... rice ... little blueberries... white wine nose ... fizzy (but its sparkling... diluted with sparkling water i think) ... definite blueberries but artificial ... rice linger ... not worth drinkin

column3:
United States;Flavored - Other;The Brew Keeper / Mad Brewer;"22 oz bottle

Overall I think Mad Brewer has done a great job of setting themselves up as a respectable local brewery. Whenever I get the chance to pick up a new release I always give it serious consideration over national releases. This particular beer is not one of their best; in this season’s crop of pumpkin ales I would place it firmly in the middle. Better than another local offering (Thirsty Dog) it falls short of being worth a second look nonetheless.

Aroma / Appearance - A deep burgandy body is graced by a huge head which takes a few minutes to settle down. Nutmeg
column4: spices
column5:
and ripe pumpkin are what you would expect to find and you do. It reminds me of a pie before the whipped cream has been swirled on.

Flavor / Palate - Squash and spices were not exactly what I had in mind when I bought the bottle. The nutmeg isn’t so bad but the slight vegetal flaw knocks this down a few points. The odd finish doesn’t help either. In the end I feel like this is a good step towards improving on it next year; as long as progress is made eventually something solid will be sold in a few years time. In the meantime save your money."

column3: United States;Flavored - Other;The Brew Keeper / Mad Brewer;Thanks to Ja Bier for sharing a bottle. The beer pours a lightly hazed brownish-amber color with a thin beige head that recedes steadily. Spotty lacing on the glass. Malty aroma with notes of brown sugar. Medium-bodied with a flavor reminiscent of apple butter. Notes of malt and spices behind the fruityness. The finish is sweet and fruity with bits of brown sugar and pumpkin left behind. Pretty good all around.

United States;Flavored - Other;The Brew Keeper / Mad Brewer;Thanks go to Nathan for the bottle! Poured much darker than anticipated.. deep cherry pit colored with just a dusting of tan head when you agitate it. The aroma picked up deep

Medium-bodied with not too great balance between the slow-moving molasses sweetness and the brighter spices and sourness.. somewhat refreshing at the finish.. OK stuff.

column3: Canada;Flavored - Other;Storm Brewing (BC);This is the second go at a Wormwood IPA. The first one was a 0.5 - totally undrinkable with bitterness far beyond anything I’ve ever tasted. This time the dose has been cut a bit. Hazy tan colour. Woody aroma - sort of a potent aroma accented by Storm’s typical earthy English hops. Massive bitterness - not as extreme as last time but still up there. And the bitterness of wormwood simply isn’t as cohesive as hop bitterness is. What isn’t overwhelmed is some of the pale malt and house yeast.

column7: maybe; but a full glass? Not me. Go figure this was the pick of the festival from the assembled brewers... Sampled on cask at Dix (Caskival 2007)."

column3: Canada;Flavored - Other;Red Truck Beer Company;"Dave Varga’s cat killed a mole and his dog brought it back and dumped it into the brew kettle despite being told repeatedly to ""sit"" and ""drop that dead thing on the floor"". Either that or this is based on mole poblano. I know my beer and I know my mole so let’s rock.Brown colour and really sludgey-looking. The aroma is sharp - oregano
column4: cinnamon
column5: pepper
column6: vinegar and way too much cumin
column7: even for a mole. Very spicy character. I like the chipotle heat; I don’t like the mouthfeel being all powdery from the overdose of cumin; I like the concept and the subtle chocolate; I don’t like the over-the-top sense of balance. It’s barely drinkable. I love cumin as much as the next guy but this is far too much.My take: The concept is great and after a few batches of adjustments this could completely rock. The first suggestion I’d make is to replace powdered cumin with toasted cumin seeds. The powder affects the mouthfeel too much and the seeds will be far less likely to overwhelm the flavour and aroma of the beer. Mole isn’t about clobbering you with one dominant characteristic
column8: it’s about blending a million different things together seamlessly. For beermaking purposes I guess the toasting would have to be done in an oven rather than by frying in oil.My second suggestion - mix up the ingredients a bit. You don’t need it all in there to replicate the key components of a mole (I’d especially skip the turkey!). I’d leave out the cinnamon and cloves entirely. The cinnamon should come from the Mexican chocolate. Only one brand I know of in Vancouver that is all-natural and thus ideal for mole (or mole beer) and that is Rey Amargo
column9: which can be found at Los Guerreros on Kingsway at Joyce. European-style chocolate is not appropriate for mole.I would also add some ancho to the mix. I love chipotle but this needs a more complex chile character. I wouldn’t want the heat to be jacked up much higher though
column10: so ancho is the best choice. I think there should be some herb character - oregano is nice
column11: maybe some epazote would be cool
column12: too. In terms of some of the other elements of a mole
column13: nuts are probably to oily to add
column14: plantains or tomatillos might be too whacked-out but some raisins wouldn’t hurt at all. Anyway

column3: Japan;Saké - Koshu;Ichinokura Shuzo Co.
column4: Ltd.;This is hands down the BEST sake I have had to date. The aroma is sweet with light fruit and just a hint of rice and alcohol. The Appearance is clear and still. The flavor is more like a desert wine than a sake but has enough rice to remind you what it is. The palate is thin but smooth. Overall this gets my highest recommendation for a sake but it is pricey.

column3: Japan;Saké - Koshu;Ichinokura Shuzo Co.
column4: Ltd.;"Enjoyed at ""15 East"" in NYC. An aged dessert sake
column5: this was quite yellow in color and had both marked sweetness and some sourness as well. It was like a glass of white dessert wine. Lots of complexity - I won’t bore you by naming all sorts of obscure fruits that I pretended to taste. This was a terrifically enjoyable koshu for those who don’t like the excessive sweetness of a Poochi Poochi or Moon Rabbit sparkling dessert sake."

United States;BarleyWine / WheatWine / RyeWine;The Brew Keeper / Mad Brewer;650 ml bottle This was a disappointment even though I set the bar low after a number of experiences with Mad Brewer. It is no shock to learn that they closed over the summer. While any brewery closing is not good news in this case the market was just too crowded to support a subpar product. Maybe they can reopen in the future after some quality control. Aroma / Appearance - Chewy brown and fluid the body has a hefty presence. Dusty cherry pie blends with the smell of a rare bookshop to form a musty hoppy profile. This seems to have mellowed since I picked it up two years ago. Flavor / Palate - Cherry pie filling sweetens the throat like a gourmet candy bar. There’s little depth to back it up despite some hoppiness that kicks back. It has shadows of promise but this bottle at least falls short of what I expect in a barleywine. This is probably going to be the last beer I pick up from Mad Brewer as I am almost certain the rest on the shelves will have fared much worse.

column1: Dodging Duck Milk & Quackers Milk Chocolate Nitro Stout;Boerne
column3: United States;Stout - Milk / Sweet;Dodging Duck Brewhaus;"FROM MY MAGAZINE COLUMN: ""BREWHOUSE BULLETIN"" (HILL COUNTRY DIRECTIONS SEPT/OCT 2007): ‘Milk & Quackers’ Milk Chocolate Nitro Stout The Dodging Duck Brewhaus – Boerne
column4: TX For a stout fan
column5: this beer is fun from start to finish: watching it pour slow from the nitrogen tap
column6: that first sip through the creamy head
column7: holding it to the light to see that none passes through the tar darkness
column8: the bold aroma of chocolate as it warms. Take in the mind-boggling smoothness. It pours dense brownish black
column10: super-tight bubbled (almost whipped) rich chocolate milk colored head. As the beer level drops
column11: it leaves a nice milky foam wall inside the glass
column12: which slowly settles until the next sip. After 5 years of making different dry stouts
column13: this is brewer Keith Moore’s first venture into the realm of the sweet stout. ‘Milk & Quackers’ is not overwhelmingly sweet as the name might suggest
column14: but it’s certainly not bone dry. Its sweetness due
column16: to lactose powder (‘milk sugar’) added towards the end of the boil. It’s subtle
column17: coming off with the aroma and beginning taste of roasted chocolate malt. The brew finishes chalky and tangy
column18: blunt and bitter. Like sucking on a square of Baker’s chocolate. The mild hops linger and play dark on the palette. Moore describes the mouthfeel as “almost crunchy!” This beer is rich
column19: but doesn’t sit heavy on the gut. At 5% ABV
column20: it’s extremely drinkable and made even more enjoyable paired with the restaurant’s bison burger or beef tenderloin medallions. For desert
column21: a pint stands alone or compliments a slice of apple pie and ice cream. If you’re not lucky enough to catch ‘Milk & Quackers’ on tap
column22: try the seasonal ‘Ducktoberfest.’ Moore’s recipe sticks to tradition
column23: using the same ingredients the Germans use. Dark orange in color
column24: it’s more malty than your regular lager. With a caramel taste that’s almost chewy."

Smell – The aroma is heaviest of a sweet caramel and a bit of toffee as well as some fruit smells of apple and a decent roasted malt smell. Along with these sweeter and maltier aromas is a moderately strong hop smell of a citrus and floral nature. Taste – The taste begins with caramel sweetness and a nice roasted malt and biscuit taste. column5: the taste sweetens as toffee and apple tastes come to the tongue. Along with these sweeter flavors coming to the tongue
column7: further enhancing the sweeter flavors. While the sweeter is enhanced
column8: it is kept in check/balance by a lightly hoppy taste of a citrus and herbal nature
column9: in the end leaving a very pleasantly balanced bitter-sweet flavor on the tongue. Mouthfeel –The body of the beer is on the medium side in terms of its thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that was on the average side as well. Both were rather appropriate for the style batching both the sweet and bitter hop flavors nicely. Overall –Some roast

column6: its a bit of a peachy-like alcohol. There is a bit of a weak feel and flavor and that is topped off by a hefty alcoholic and white bread maltiness. In general there is a bit of a rumble tumble feel to the beer
column7: not well balanced despite tasting good. Just needs some more lagering to even out the alcoholic edges. But I would have this again as blond doppelbocks are few and far between.

column3: Canada;Belgian Ale - Strong Pale;Trafalgar Ales and Meads;Bottle at Tied House Unlike many people I found this to not be all that bad. Viewed in the light of a 17% ABV beer it lacks the flaws that some other ultra-high gravity beers possess. I would not drink more than a 200ml bottle but for something to warm the senses on a cold winter night it works quite well. I think this shows that hidden gems can exist among those love/hate beers of the world. Aroma / Appearance - Very flat with no carbonation as you would expect this swirled around the glass like a fortified wine. The nose was smoky like bacon and warm motor oil. Cherry seeds provide another layer of texture. For 17% it was not nearly as heavy as I expected it to be. Flavor / Palate - Heavy and cloying I did not detect many of the notes of soy as other people have. Warm through the palate it sits around a long time. Had I not eaten dinner a few minutes later it would probably have lasted for twenty minutes or more. This interesting beer is an experiment that seems to have gone mostly right.

column3: England;Perry;Minchews Real Cyder & Perry;Polycask at Merton Summer Beer Festival July 19th This is one of those drinks that has to live up to its famous name following the instant popularity
column4: courtsey of Wallace and Grommit. We had a good chat with Kevin Minchew the owner/producer of this cidery and were shown around his wonderfully chaotic but very historic machinery
column5: Kevin knew his stuff and this Perry shows that quite magnificently. I also couldn’t help but think that the strange aroma had more than a passing similarity to the cheese (or just chess in general) or was that just the name playing in my mind? I don’t think so it was a touch cheesy. Poured light gold and quite interesting for a Perry in that i didn’t get the big juicy overipe pears that I often get
column6: this was a bit more complex quite dry at times but the sweetness was there it just that it was well reined in
column7: a hint of rhubarb played across my tongue once or twice and all in all a most enjoyable Perry. BTW I note that Kevin informed us that this Perry is actually the excat same Perry as the Malvern Hills version he does
column8: Kevin said that he is ofetn requested to change the name depending on what side of the Malverns he sells it. It must be a Herefordshire and Worcestershire thing.

column3: United States;Tripel;Central Waters Brewing Co.;"On tap at GTMW 2007 Since Central Waters typically releases good beers I thought I would give this one a shot. The best word I can think of to describe it is underwhelming. While it wasn’t exactly disappointing I was left wondering if there was another aspect to it that had gotten cooked out in the heat. I might have another pint of this if I ever get to the brewery but this shouldn’t be bottled at the expense of anything else. Aroma / Appearance - The cloudy mandarin orange body was a bit unusual but not totally unexpected. Oranges
column4: coriander and cloves were most obvious but a soap background was a little offputting. It was fairly simple for a tripel if that is the style they were aiming for. Flavor / Palate - Cotton candy
column5: soap and apple butter create a very unimpressionable flavor profile. The mouthfeel is creamy enough but lacks any punch to set it apart from any other tripel out there. In fact this is subpar even when compared to most American made releases. It’s still not totally poor; I would drink it again if I found it at the brewpub. I probably would stay away from a six pack though."

column3: United States;Helles / Dortmunder Export;Half Acre Beer Company;Enjoyed on tap at the Half Acre taproom. Served in a pint glass. Some mild citrus with a lager yeast sweetness. T: Same as the nose. The Vienna malt is stronger and sweeter than the nose. Lagery yeast is present again with very light grass and fruity hops on the backend providing a touch of bitterness. M: Light bodied with a medium carbonation level. Sweet malt finish. O: Solid lager overall. Wouldn’t order this too often

column1: Church Brew St. James Biere De Garde;Pittsburgh
column3: United States;Belgian Ale - Pale / Golden;Church Brew Works;A- Medium Brown body with ruby
column4: rose
column5: and plum highlights. The color of this brew is simply beautiful. Pours with a thin 1/2 finger white head that eventually fades completely. Little to no lacing is left behind in the glass. S- Light nose. Earthy cellar-like esters and spicy belgian yeast dominate with dark fruits and caramel malt in the background. T- Spicy Belgian yeast and dark fruits like plum and grape upfront. Caramel malt and mild hops can be noted in the background. Finish is a balance of spicy ale yeast and caramel malt. A slight alcohol burn kicks in at the very end. Spicy yeast and caramel malt with a hint of earthy esters linger. P- Medium carbonation and yeasty body. Goes down fairly easy. O- The alcohol is quite noticeable in this brew but that is characteristic of the style. Its a tasty brew with a decent mouthfeel and it was good enough for me to bring a growler home with me. I hope this is something that CBW decides to put on rotating release. Great experience for my first brew of this style. Serving type: growler Reviewed on: 08-12-2007 01:33:28

column1: Grumpy Troll Maggie Imperial IPA (Bourbon Barrel);Mount Horeb
column3: United States;IIPA - Imperial / Double IPA;Grumpy Troll Brewery
column4: Restaurant and Pizzeria;"On tap at brewpub This was the real reason for a Saturday visit. I hope this is on tap in a week’s time when I head out again. It is one of the better imperial IPAs I have tried. The barrel aging really compliments the natural flavors well. Give it a try if you can make it there in the next few weeks. Aroma / Appearance - The chestnut brown body looked just like the regular Maggie IPA. The head was the color of pale ash. Oak
column5: vanilla
column6: caramel and old pine enrich the senses. The bourbon is stronger than the base beer but not by much. To approximate the overall aroma take bourbony notes and combine them with chocolate brownie mix. Flavor / Palate - The creamy mouthfeel coats the throat in warm estery goodness. There is a hint of booziness but not enough to overwhelm the dry aftertaste which is not unlike licking a spruce tree (or making a pine needle smoothie). Oak
column8: chocolate syrup and caramel float on the tongue as it begins to warm. The opening is all bourbon; the close all imperial IPA. It is very well balanced and worth the visit."

column3: United States;IPA;Lagunitas Brewing Company (Heineken);Sometimes cheaper bombers doesn’t mean subpar beer. That’s the case with this gem. I think I paid $3 for a bomber of this double IPA and it was very very good. A-Yellow clear pour with a 2+ head with a good retention S-citrus and floural hops. Fresh grass smell T-Fresh citrus and hops with a great lasting bitterness M-light and carbonated D-Very drinkable and a great all around IPA.
